title: Kristian Woolf
text:
Kristian Woolf (born 6 July 1975) is an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football coach who is the head coach of <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St Helens</a> in the <a href="Betfred%20Super%20League">Betfred Super League</a> and <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> at international level. 
He previously was the interim head coach of the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>. 
Playing career.
Hailing from <a href="Mount%20Isa">Mount Isa, Queensland</a>, Woolf played for the <a href="Souths%20Magpies">Souths Magpies</a> in <a href="Brisbane%2C%20Australia">Brisbane</a> between 1996 and 1997.
Coaching career.
In 2002, Woolf began his coaching career as an assistant coach for the Townsville Brothers in the Townsville & District Rugby League (TDRL) competition. At the same time, Woolf was teaching at <a href="Ignatius%20Park%20College">Ignatius Park College</a> and coaching their senior rugby league side, winning the Queensland State Schoolboys Championship in 2004.
In 2005, Woolf joined the <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland Cowboys</a> as their junior development manager. After holding the role for four seasons, Woolf became the team's <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">NYC</a> coach in 2009. He took the side to the finals for the first time in 2010 and to their first Grand Final in 2011, which they lost in <a href="golden%20point">golden point</a> to the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a>.
In 2012, Woolf joined the <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos">Brisbane Broncos</a> as an assistant coach to <a href="Anthony%20Griffin%20%28rugby%20league%29">Anthony Griffin</a>.
In 2015, he returned to North Queensland as the inaugural coach of the new <a href="Intrust%20Super%20Cup">Intrust Super Cup</a> side, the <a href="Townsville%20Blackhawks">Townsville Blackhawks</a>. In the club's first season, the side finished in first place and qualified for the Grand Final, losing to the <a href="Ipswich%20Jets">Ipswich Jets</a>.
Woolf was appointed head coach of the <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tongan national team</a> in 2014. In October 2015, Woolf recorded his first win with Tonga in the <a href="2017%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28Asia-Pacific%20play-off%29">Asia-Pacific</a> 2017 World Cup qualifying game against the <a href="Cook%20Islands%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Cook Islands</a>. In 2016, Woolf's Tonga team suffered a second straight defeat by Samoa in the <a href="Pacific%20Rugby%20League%20International%23Polynesian%20Cup%202">Polynesian Cup</a>.
On 26 September 2018, Woolf officially left his role as Blackhawks' head coach, which he held for four seasons, to take up an assistant coaching position with the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a>.
On 27 August 2019, Woolf was named interim head coach with Newcastle for the remainder of the 2019 season after <a href="Nathan%20Brown%20%28rugby%20league%2C%20born%201973%29">Nathan Brown</a> stepped down.
On 10 September 2019, it was announced that Woolf would take up the head coach role at <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in 2020, signing a two-year contract with the club having the option to extend a further year.
He coached St Helens in the club's 8-4 <a href="2020%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">2020 Super League Grand Final</a> victory over Wigan at the <a href="Kingston%20Communications%20Stadium">Kingston Communications Stadium</a> in Hull.
He coached St. Helens to victory in the <a href="2021%20Challenge%20Cup%20Final">2021 Challenge Cup Final</a> with a 26-12 victory over <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>.
On 9 October 2021, Woolf coached St. Helens to their <a href="2021%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">2021 Super League Grand Final</a> victory over <a href="Catalans%20Dragons">Catalans Dragons</a>.
Personal life.
Woolf's brother, Ben, is the current coach of the <a href="Tweed%20Heads%20Seagulls">Tweed Heads Seagulls</a> <a href="Queensland%20Cup">Queensland Cup</a> side.
His sister Katie Woolf is one of Australia’s only female commercial talkback radio broadcasters, on Mix FM Darwin.
<a href="https%3A//www.mix1049.com.au/360-with-katie-woolf/meet-katie">Meet Katie Woolf</a>
